boardgame.name: Malifaux: Arachnid Swarm
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

The Steampunk Arachnid Swarm is the primary workhorse for crews led by Ramos, but you can utilize them with any Arcanist crews, and even in crews led by C. Hoffman or Leveticus. This model is typically well worth the 9 SS cost, and overall has good survivability, a good attack, and consistent damage output.

Overall, the Arachnids are pretty straight forward, and are basic melee attack units.

On the other hand Scatter uses a Summon technique, so if you plan to do the Scatter action, always be sure to use 1 general AP for something else first, and use your (+2) Melee Master and probably Self Repair or Disruption Field as well. Then when you Scatter, if you activated Disruption Field, it will automatically pass onto each of your newly summoned individual Arachnids. When they come into play, since they are Summoned, they are treated as new models, each with their own activation, but they will be Slow during that turn which they were summoned. The Scatter action is also different from Swarm Together, in that the individual Arachnids do not activate immediately, as in the Swarm Together scenario.

Against models with high Df, as mentioned above, Latch On is typically a good approach. One thing that works well is to move a Swarm up to the opponent, as long as it's less than 4" total, attack twice with (+2) Melee Master, activate (0) Disruption Field, and then use the Swarm's last (1) to Scatter. Since you have to put the individual Arachnids in base contact with the Swarm, you should be able to place at least two of the new Arachnids in base contact with your target. Then, when those individual ones get to activate (thus, good to do this at the end of your turn, after your opponent has activated all their models, if possible), you start out with the one not in base contact to move into base contact and (0) Latch On. Then your two Arachnids in base contact can (0) Latch On and attack vs -4 and -6 Df. If you can manage to set this up where your Steamborg Executioner or another Arachnid Swarm still need to activate after all of this, then you should be able to really do some damage. This is one of the best ways to handle high Df opponents like Lilith, Perdita Ortega, or the Coryphee Duet (if you can get them to stand still, that is).

Lastly, the Overwhelm trigger, as mentioned above is one of the most dangerous things about the Arachnid Swarm, and it is worth learning how to utilize it well, both in the game itself, and as a psychological tactic. If your opponent knows that you have not yet activated a Swarm or two in range of some of his better pieces, he may be cautious about playing higher cards from his hand earlier in the turn, because he wants to keep those for cheating up his Df against the potential Swarm attacks. So there are some good mind-games that can be utilized with the Swarm.

boardgame.name: Crown of Underworld
boardgame.description:
user summary
Players compete as mafia bosses for the most influence in Munshine City.

Each player takes one of 8 different families/organisations, each with special powers.

The game takes 10 turns, divided into phases of which the most important are:

Bribing phase: The players bid blindly on one or more of 6 so called Key Figures, which convey special powers in the following turn.

Planing Phase: The players plan their next moves by adding influence tokens to the board, hiring or assigning gangster cards, so called suspects, to the tasks of attacking, defending or collecting income. Those assignments are secret.

Venality phase: Bribes are revealed and Key Figures' powers used.

Combat phase: Players who planned on attacking use their suspects to attack another player. Results are given by the value of attacking and defending suspects and the number of influence tokens on the attacked area.

Cash In / Cash Out Phase: Planned moves must be payed, otherwise a penalty is taken. Income is collected.

All the while, players can play event cards on each other.

After 10 turns, a winner is determined by the number and position of controlled areas, with some extras for number of suspects or cash.


quoting from the manual
Crown of Underworld is strategic card-driven boardgame! It's hybrid nature merging two different kinds of game engines offers something absolutely new for fans of this kind of entertainment. Players struggle on many levels simultaneously to earn advantage and ultimately - the victory.
The game develops planning skills and ability to use own advantages and see weaknesses of others to dominate competitors. Unlike many games, Crown of Underworld is completely different with each game. On the other hand, non-linear nature of the turn-flow, created by random sequence of events affecting each turn promotes flexible players.
We hope you will enjoy playing Crown of Underworld as much as we had fun when we designed it!

boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

The Depths of Greed is an adventure scenario designed for three to six characters of any class. In this adventure, the characters stumble upon a massacre at an isolated roadside inn and get swept up in the defense of its survivors. After fending off a brutal assault from the highway brigands, the players venture to their isolated lair along the windswept shores of the Barren Sea, and there unearth an ancient secret.

While we break a contemporary cardinal rule of not starting an adventure in an inn, we decided we wanted to show how the trope could still be used if done well. Six premade characters are provided at the end of this module for your use. We would love to hear about your group’s adventure on our forums, and if any of you continue your N.R.G. campaign beyond this module, we
would love (love!) to hear about that as well! (And who knows, your exploits might even end up in one of our future sourcebooks!)

boardgame.name: Tesla vs. Edison: War of Currents
boardgame.description:
Tesla vs. Edison: War of Currents is a fast-playing, route building, economic and worker placement game focused on invention and industry in the roaring 1880's. It is easy-to-learn and appropriate for all gamers aged 14 and up.

Nikola Tesla, Thomas Edison, and three other important inventors of the time struggle to determine who will be most remembered as the man who brought light to the masses. Contributing innovations in power generation, delivery, and illumination, you also choose to invest in Direct Current (DC) technology or the superior but later developing AC technology.

Players control a small group of legendary figures from the War of Currents, each rated in Invention, Engineering, Finance and Public Relations. Each turn these legends are allocated to help research, commercialize or patent technology; influence the public's perception about the inventors and AC or DC technology; bid on and hopefully secure either residential, exhibition or power generation projects in cities around the 1880's United States. Money is tight and players may need to sell shares of their company in order to do everything they need to succeed. But be careful: other companies can buy stock you release, and the winner is the player whose company's stock is worth the most at the end of the game!

boardgame.name: The Heir
boardgame.description:
A playbook for tremulus.

From Introduction:

You have always felt apart, different, as though you didn’t belong anywhere. You attended university, got a nice job, and found a place where you could live out a mundane, ordinary existence. Somewhere deep within, you knew it couldn’t last. It began with the letters from a place you never heard of, a place you felt called to you, and you let them languish, unopened, and unread. Afraid of what they might contain. You had been warned to always avoid that side of the family. Then the man came, an attorney with a briefcase, a ticket, and a deed to your ancestral home. You felt a sudden release, as though you’d been holding your breath all these years, and decided to see for yourself if there was really a future for you somewhere else in a place less ordinary, a place where you might belong, a place you could call your home.

boardgame.name: Dyami, le petit Indien
Kleine Vos wordt Grote Beer
Kleiner Fuchs ganz gro
Little Big Fox
Pequeo Gran Zorro
Piccola Grande Volpe
boardgame.description:
A Native-American themed memory game for children.

Background story: Little Fox, a young Native American wants to be as brave as his father. He is sent out on his own to complete several difficult tasks. Can you help Little Fox succeed?

Aim of the game:
Being the first to complete 5 tasks.

Setup:
The 10 Indian path tiles are placed in a circle in random order. 7 tiles show tasks. The remaining 3 tiles show the sun, moon and the wise shaman. The 28 bush tiles are placed around the Indian path (on the face-down side, they show the same pictures as the ones on the path tiles). Each player gets a teepee board that has 5 slots for bush tiles. The Little Fox token is placed on the shaman path tile.

Gameplay:
Players take turns rolling the die and advancing Little Fox the corresponding number of spaces on the Indian path. If Little Fox lands on a task tile, the active player turns over a bush tile. If the bush tile shows the same picture as the task tile, the player gets to keep it and place it on his/her teepee board. If it is the wrong bush tile, it remains face-up.
If Little Fox lands on the sun tile, three bush tiles are turned over, then the die is rolled again. If Little Fox lands on the moon tile, all bush tiles that are face-up are turned face-down again. If Little Fox lands on the shaman tile, the player gets to take a tile of their choice.

The first player to have collected 5 bush tiles (= to have completed 5 tasks) wins the game.

Variants to increase difficulty include immediately turning bush tiles face-down again, and letting only the active player see a bush tile on the moon space.

boardgame.name: Rugrats in Paris: The Movie
boardgame.description:
Rugrats in Paris: The Movie is a video game based on the movie of the same name from the Nickelodeon animated series, Rugrats. The game follows the adventures of a group of young children in a European theme park. A Sega Dreamcast version of the game was planned to be made, but it later got cancelled.
Tommy Pickles' father has been sent to Europe in order to fix a broken robot at EuroReptar Land and has decided to bring his family and friends with him. The player can choose Tommy, Chuckie, Phil, Lil, Angelica, and Kimi to play as. There are approx 16 levels as well as hidden bonus levels in both single and multi-player games. The object of the game is to collect enough gold Reptar tickets to buy the Reptar Helmet that controls a Giant Robot Reptar. The PC version does not include collecting Reptar tickets, and it seems to be centered more around Chuckie and his concern about his father, who plans to re-marry.

Source: Wikipedia, "Rugrats in Paris: The Movie (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Beeren klau'n mit Schnabelgrn
boardgame.description:
Raven Schnabelgrün loves blueberries. He flies around and picks up as many as possible.
To play, set up a circly of meadow tiles - they are lake tiles on the other side. Randomly distribute the large wooden blueberries on the tiles (up to three per tile). Schnabelgrün starts on one of the tiles. The active player draws a card which determines the distance the raven can move (1, 2 or 3 tiles). The player then picks up any blueberries on that tile. If there are none, the player flips over an empty meadow tile instead. If Schnabelgrün lands on a lake tile, the active player needs to put down two blueberries on that field to help the raven stay afloat. Some cards also let the player steal a berry from another player.
The game ends when a player runs out of berries. The player with most berries is the winner.

boardgame.name: Admiral
boardgame.description:
'Admiral' is a Board Gaming System that provides players an opportunity to act as commander of the sailing ships fleet at the Epoch of the Sail (XVI-XVIII centuries). At their disposal – all the fighting techniques of sailing ships:
- 100-gun First Rate Ships,
- fast and furious frigates,
- firepower of galleons
- maneuverability of brigs.
Use also advantages of enemy ships boarding, fire-ships (i.e., ships-bombs) and naval mines!
Please dive into the period of 3 centuries when sailing ships were masters of the seas and oceans!

Despite all of this diversity, the game can be quickly mastered by both experienced players and those who are only acquainted with the fascinating world of naval strategic board games. To do this, the game has several levels of difficulty that help to master the most complex techniques according to real conditions of naval battles of the epoch.

Various game scenarios are also available. They will allow to play either direct confrontation of naval armada or hunt for the gold fleet or assault pirate port!

Short description and advantages of the Game:
1. Romantic (not cruel) naval game about ‘sail epoch’ for meeting and communication of all the family or other good company (starting from 6-8 years till 99, 8+ recommended).
2. Different levels of difficulty and different scenarios (impact on number of participants [2-6, 3-4 recommended), age, time [30-120 minutes, 80 is average for experienced players], goal of the game [resources collection, opponents defeat]).
3. Game mechanics closely related to the naval story, usage of wind direction and strength (determined with a weathercock) as one of the main drivers of uncertainty!
4. Very nice miniatures of warships (you will enjoy their fun and easy construction (no glue!) and, if you wish, recolor them according to your tastes or tastes of you children) PLUS usage of magnets for small elements of playing cards for your convenience.
5. The rules with separate not obligatory for reading chapter on history of the ‘sail epoch’, written in a romantic manner.
6. A map can be configured by means of overlay components according to the scenario and will of the players.
7. The game was tested in different countries by 6-10 years children [incl.girls], 15-40 year men and women, and board game geeks. And was admired by most of them, and purchased after testing by some of them.

boardgame.name: Wonderland
boardgame.description:
Text from the rulebook:
The characters in this attractive game for young people are taken from the famous “Alice in Wonderland,” and brightly illustrated in colors.

The card “ALICE” is the particular one which the players most desire to retain in their hands, as, after all the cards have been played, the player holding “Alice” WINS the Game.

There are duplicates in the pack of every card except “Alice.”
Shuffle the cards and deal, one at a time, to each player.
All cards in a player’s hand that will match, after being dealt, are thrown aside.

The dealer begins by drawing a card from the player at his right hand, the player drawn from holding the cards so that the dealer cannot see what he is drawing.

If the card drawn will pair with something in the dealer’s hand, he throws both aside; if not, he retains it.

Whether it pairs or not, it then becomes the turn of the player from whom the card was drawn to draw from the player at HIS right.

When a player entirely runs out of cards, he stops playing and the game continues without him.
The game thus proceeds, drawing and matching, until “Alice” alone is left.

The last player holding “Alice” WINS THE GAME.

boardgame.name: Shello
boardgame.description:
from the designer's site:

Shello is a game for 2 players, played with chips that are white on one side and black on the other, on a 9×9 square grid (or larger, as long as there are an odd number of cells in the grid. But 9×9 is all you’ll need for a long time.)

The game starts with a set board layout.

The pieces in the corners are called Neutral Pieces. These count as both black and white. They never move and they’re never flipped, but they can be used to flip pieces of either color during the game.

Rules

1. One player plays pieces black side up, and the other plays them white side up. Starting with Black, the players take turns. On your turn you must either:
A) place a piece on an empty space orthogonally-adjacent to any friendly piece, or
B) move any friendly piece, by a chess queen’s move, to any empty space not orthogonally adjacent to any friendly pieces.

2. If you have no legal moves, you must pass.

3. After placing or moving a piece, flip all enemy pieces lying in an uninterrupted straight orthogonal or diagonal row between the piece you placed or moved and any friendly pieces.

4. The game ends when the board is full. The player with more pieces on the board wins.

boardgame.name: Snype
boardgame.description:
from the designer's site:

Snype is a game for 2 players, played with black and white stones, on an initially empty board hex-hex board. (Snype is an attempt to create a Y-like game, without the overwhelming strategic importance of the center spaces.)

Rules
* To begin, one player places a white stone on any empty space, and the other player decides whether to play as White or Black.
* From then on, starting with Black, the players take turns. A turn consists of two actions, which may be performed in any order: 1) place a stone of your color on any numbered empty space; and 2) optionally, move a stone in a straight line, any number of spaces up to the number on the space from which it starts, so that it lands on an empty numbered space. No jumping allowed.
* The game ends when one player creates a connected group of stones which is adjacent to at least one blue, one yellow and one red space. He wins.

No need for a game master! Play in one hour! Complete with a dungeon scenario that can be enjoyed time after time!

boardgame.name: Protour
boardgame.description:
Out-golf up to 71 simultaneous opponents in this riveting game of strategy and luck. Choose between 9 and 18 holes to make the game longer or shorter (about 1-2 hours of play time). Each of the 18 holes is represented by a unique, hand-drawn map of the area, which is divided into small segments to help players gauge the approximate distance from the tee-off point to the green. Players use different colors of golf ball pawns to track their progress across each map. Just as with actual golf, players will attempt to complete the game in the fewest number of "strokes" possible. For each stroke, a player will first decide whether or not they wish to spin for a "distance bonus"--a free number of segments they are allowed to move their pawn toward the hole. This can be advantageous, but a bad spin also has the potential to land the player in a dangerous sand trap or water hazard (both of which carry a stroke penalty), so the decision should not be made lightly. After resolving or skipping this spin, the player then decides how many dice to throw, from 1 to 3, attempting to land as close to the green as possible. Each pip on the dice represents the player's ball moving forward 1 segment; therefore, if too many or too few dice are thrown, players can easily fall short of, or overshoot, their goal. Once a player lands on the green, they attempt to putt their way into the hole, which involves slightly different dice-rolling mechanics.

At the beginning of the game, each player is also given a number of Skill Cards which can be spent in various ways:
1. A Skill Card can be discarded before a roll to add an extra die. This is helpful for players who wish to have a longer drive, thereby increasing their chances of avoiding a large number of hazards or traps near the center of a map.
2. If a player does land in a hazard or trap, he or she may discard a Skill Card to ignore the stroke penalty of that hazard or trap.
3. A Skill Card may be used to change one die result on a player's putting roll, thereby refining the putting accuracy.
4. Finally, any unspent Skill Cards can be used at the end of the game to subtract a stroke from one's own score, or to add a stroke to an opponent's score.

Also includes a solo variant in which the player attempts to finish all 18 holes in under 72 strokes. This goal is then adjusted according to the player's level of success.

boardgame.name: Mayhem Mines
boardgame.description:
Mayhem Mines is a card game in which 2-4 players compete to collect the most treasure before tremors collapse the mine. The game takes between 10 and 25 minutes to play. In the game, players mine for treasure, sabotage other miners, and avoid traps and monsters such as the infamous Greedy Dragon!

Mayhem Mines is an incredibly simple card game with the objective being that at the end of the game, be the player that holds the most Treasure.

The game consists of of 4 types of cards.

Treasure Cards (Blue): These are what you are searching for! Have the most at the end of the game and you win!

Event Cards (Yellow): When you draw an event card its effect takes place immediately and you reveal the card and follow the text.

Actions Cards (Green): An action card is held in your hand until you wish to play it.

Tremor Cards (Red): Tremor cards are revealed and stay on the field.

The game is played by shuffling and dealing the entire deck of cards on to a play surface face down. Then on each of your turns you have two options, Search the Mine (pick up a card form the playing field), or Play an Action Card. Keep in mind, that some Actions Cards allow you to search as well!

This continues until 3 Tremors are caused by either revealing them in the mine or using the “Jack the Hammer” tremor causing card, the game ends immediately and a winner is determined. Add up the values of all your treasure cards. The player with the highest is crowned the winner.

boardgame.name: Ultimate Soldier
boardgame.description:
The game is for 2-6 players and is played in rounds. There are usually 3-4 rounds in a game. Game play lasts 20-40 minutes. It is a quick paced game involving strategic combat. Outwit and outmuscle your opponents to become the Ultimate Soldier.  

To begin each player will start with 1 Soldier card, a Reference card, and eight Common cards. The first player to draw a Common card begins. They can make one of three moves during their turn.
Play a Training Academy card (When the equivalent of four Training Academies is met, they earn another Soldier card).
Mount an assault against another soldier, which can include enhancements from Weapons and Intensity cards (If your soldier dies and you do not have another one trained, you cannot mount an assault).
Discard because they are unable to make another move.

The game is played in rounds; the first player to either earn or have four soldiers alive, or win in three separate combats, wins the round. Players then get to draw Victory cards for winning the round or surviving the round with a Soldier card. The first player to earn seven Victory cards wins. If a player loses three or more battles during a round, they must surrender a Victory card. 

The game is designed to keep everyone involved throughout the game even if it is not their turn. For instance, during combat, a player can use a Deflection card to send the assault to someone else. During combat, if a player doesn't have cards to retaliate, but has a Radio for Help card, they get to draw two cards from anyone not in combat. There are also plenty of surprises, so don't leave the table for anything:  

The Sniper: a card that can be played at any time even when it is not that player's turn. The sniper takes out a soldier without recourse. However, if the player being shot by the sniper holds a Mirror card, they can use it to reflect the light into the sniper's eyes and survive. 

The Bomb: a card that can be played at any time, even when it is not that player's turn. The bomb kills one soldier in every player's hand, unless they hold a Dud or Super Dud card. The Dud card saves the soldier of the player that holds it. The Super Dud saves all the soldiers on the table. If you are on the way to victory, you might want to just hold onto the Super Dud and watch your foes explode.

boardgame.name: Star Wars (Sega 1998)
Star Wars Trilogy Arcade
boardgame.description:
Star Wars Trilogy Arcade is an arcade game first released in 1998. The game is a 3-D rail shooter based on the original trilogy of Star Wars films and was released along with the special editions of these films. It is the second Star Wars arcade game released by Sega, following 1993's Star Wars Arcade.

Normal gameplay involves the player moving a crosshair around the screen using a joystick and pressing the fire button atop the joystick to shoot. A "special event" button lights at certain points of the game and when pressed, triggers an event to happen onscreen. The game puts the player in several key battles of the Star Wars films with one mission for each original Star Wars film. The player selects which film's mission to play first and each mission has two parts.

Source: Wikipedia, "Star Wars Trilogy Arcade", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Travel Trivia: Birds & Beasts
Travel Trivia: Fact & Fiction
Travel Trivia: Heroes & Villains
Travel Trivia: People & Places
Travel Trivia: Pop & Pop Stars
Travel Trivia: Sport & Games
Travel Trivia: TV & Cartoons
Travel Trivia: Wheels & Wings
boardgame.description:
Game One
Two or more players. One question master.
Object of the Game The winning player is the first to win an agreed number of cards by correctly answering one question per card.
Gameplay: The question master holds the pack of cards question side up, the first player selects any question from 1 to 6 on the card held by the question master If he answers correctly that card is awarded (and is retained question aide up to avoid looking at the answers for future games). If the question is either not answered or answered incorrectly, then any other player with the right answer Is similarly rewarded with that card. If no player answers correctiy. the question master replaces that card to the bottom of the pack. The game continues with each player in turn until one player wins the agreed number ot cards.
Variation
If there is a spread of ages and abilities, give every one a chance by giving greater rewards to younger players. Try — Ages 8 to 11 three cards per answer; Ages 11 to 14 two cards per answer; Ages 14+ one card per answer.
Game Two for Two Players
Object of the Game: The winning player is the first to win an agreed number of cards by correctly answering, according to age and ability, a minimum number of questions per card.
Gameplay: The first pfayer is question master and asks the second player questions from the top card of the pack which is placed question side up. The card is won by answering enough questions correctly. Ages 8-11 score 2/6 to win; Ages 11*14 score 3/6 to win; Ages 14 + score 4/6 to win. When all the questions on a card have
been asked or the card won, the second player becomes question master for the next card. Play continues until one player wins the agreed number of cards.
Game Three
Two or more players. One question master/scorer. Score pad + pencil required.
Object of the Game: The winner is the player scoring the most points over an agreed number of rounds.
Gameplay: Question master asks each player in turn a question. If the player answers correctly two points are awarded, failure to answer or incorrect answer, allows the other players to answer for one point. The first player to do this correctly is awarded the point. However, if different ages and abilities are participating the rewards for correct answers may vary.

If you have collected several Travel Trivia Games set a different subject for each round.

boardgame.name: BattleTech: Total Chaos
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

In late 3067, the Word of Blake unleashed its Jihad, fanning the flames of violence and spreading it across the Inner Sphere. Three mercenary commands struggled to find their footing and profit from the all-encompassing warfare. As they navigated their way through the conflicts erupting on hundreds of worlds, these mercenaries grew in power, prestige, and character. Facing adversity, victory, defeat, and enemies within and without, they were typical of many commands touched — for ill or for good—by the Jihad. As the Jihad unfolded through the Jihad Hot Spots plotbooks, players were introduced to the Chaos Campaign, a new game play system that gave players the opportunity to craft their own games around specific battles and events of the Jihad. Now that campaign, spanning fourteen years of conflict, has been collected and updated. Presented here are all of the Chaos Campaign tracks from the Hot Spots plotbooks and interwoven with select tracks from the Jihad Turning Points e-publication series and several all-new tracks and mini-campaigns.



This volume also includes detailed reports on nearly forty planetary campaigns, providing context and details previously clouded by interstellar media, local reports, and personal journals. With an updated and streamlined core ruleset for the Chaos Campaign and new Jihad era Random Availability Tables for the Word of Blake, Mercenaries, and Militias, this book has everything players and gamemasters need to recreate the pivotal campaigns of the Jihad and lead their forces to victory.


The Total Chaos expansion for BattleTech provides dozens of scenarios for BattleTech games set within the timeframe of the Jihad; in addition to collecting together those already published within various of the Jihad sourcebooks, Total Chaos adds more than 60 completely new tracks, all of which can be fought as one-off games or which can be linked together to provide long-running campaigns for groups of players.

boardgame.name: Soccer: The Great New Card Game
boardgame.description:
Interesting card game that marries Poker to a team-building football game. There are 54 cards in four 'suits' of eleven and ten reserve cards. The 'suits' are four football teams - Red Rovers, Blue Devils, Green Goblins and Yellow Dwarfs. A team consists of 1 Goalkeeper, 2 Full Backs, 2 Half Backs and 5 Forwards.

Each player receives an equal number of counters. At the start of every hand, a player must pay i unit into the Big Pool (a 'pot' that is taken by the winning player). Everyone then get five cards and can chooseto keep the hand or to discard any number of cards and receive replacements. Once this has been done for everybody, each player may discard the hand or support it. If he does indeed support it, he must pay three units into the Small Pool After everyone has had the chance to discard or support their hand, the hands left in are revealed and the winning player takes the Small Pool. The hands are valued as in Poker, except that it is possible to have five of a kind.

The winning player of each hand may take from his winning hand any cards that he might be needing to form his team. For example, if he was collecting red players and he won the hand with cards Red Full Back x 2 and a red forward, he may take those three cards and lay them out in front of him. When any player has all 11 players of the same colour, he has won. Reserve team players can be in the team, substituting for actual red player cards.

If you run out of units, you are out of the game. The player who first builds a complete team wins and takes the units in the Big Pool. The units seem only to be interesting if you are playing for real money. If not, their only function is to remove a player from the game should that player lose all his units.

boardgame.name: Gyles Brandreth's 300 Jokes Series: Animal Crackers!
Gyles Brandreth's 300 Jokes Series: Doctor Doctor!
Gyles Brandreth's 300 Jokes Series: Down With Skool!
Gyles Brandreth's 300 Jokes Series: Knock Knock!
Gyles Brandreth's 300 Jokes Series: Monster Madness
Gyles Brandreth's 300 Jokes Series: Ridulous Riddles!
boardgame.description:
Game One for two players. The winning player is (he first to win an agreed number of cards by correctly giving the punchline to one of the jokes on the card.

Shuffle the cards and place them joke side up in the centre. Player one is the Joke Teller and asks player two one of the jokes from the top card. The card is won by giving the correct punchline, If the correct punchline is not given the card is placed to the bottom of the pack. Player two is then the Joke Teller and asks player one a joke on the next card.
Play continues like this until one player wins the agreed number of cards.

Game Two: FIVE CARD TRICK for two or more players plus a Joke Teller.
The winning player is the first to win five cards.
The Joke Teller shuffles the pack and draws the top card. The player seated on the left of the Joke Teller goes first and begins by choosing any number between one and six. The Joke Teller then reads out that joke. If the first player can supply the correct purchline he wins the card. If he cannot supply the punchline or offers an incorrect punchline, the player to his left is given the chance to answer. If that player gives the correct punchline he wins the card. If he fails then the player to his left is given a chance and so on round the group. When the correct punchline has been given, the player who gave it is awarded the card, or when no correct punchline has been given, the card is placed at the bottom of the pack. It is then the second player's turn. He chooses any number between one and six and the Joke Teller reads out the joke. The process is repeated until one player has won five cards. That player is the winner.

Game Three: JOKERS WILD for three to six players.
The winner is the player with most cards at the end of the game.
The cards are shuffled and placed in the middle of the players. Player No 1 picks the top card and reads out a joke on the card. If one of the other players thinks he knows the punchline,that player shouts out “Joker!” and gives the punchline. If the punchline given is correct that player wins the card. If it is incorrect the card is placed at the bottom of the pack and the player who gave the wrong punchline misses one round which means that he cannot give the punchline to the next joke even if he knows it. It is then the turn of Player No 2 to pick a card from the pack and read out a Joke. The process is repeated round and round the group until all the cards have been won, and the player with most cards is the winner. A player cannot offer a punchline to a joke he is reading out himself. If two players shout “Joker!” at exactly the same moment the younger of the players gets to offer the punchline.

For a variation on the three games try the following: even if a player gives an incorrect punchline, the Joke Teller may award that player the card if they decide that the alternative punchline given is clever or funny enough.

boardgame.name: Epoch
boardgame.description:
Subtitle: Experimental Paradigm of Cinematic Horror

From the introduction:
EPOCH is a game of character-driven survival horror. The goal is to deliver a tense and scary experience in a single game session.

There will be blood… EPOCH is a game of survival horror, and much like a movie, not all of the characters can expect to survive until the final scene. Unlike many other games, EPOCH players have complete control over the fate of their characters. They may know the rules of the horror genre, but who becomes a victim, and how, is different every time.

There will be drama… EPOCH rewards interesting character play with increased chances of character survival. Players are not just the protagonists, but also act as the audience who hold the fate of all the characters in their hands. Using a simple, flexible, character creation method, players shape their back story to reveal interesting facts and surprising twists.

There will be a reckoning… EPOCH assumes a high level of character competence. Skills and abilities are streamlined, placing the focus back on the characters’ story and the personal impact of the horror. But victory is never assured; evil may prevail, and the true cost of the horror is never fully revealed until the final credits roll.

boardgame.name: Agricola: Brakelhhner Promo Card
Agricola: Chickens Promo Card
boardgame.description:
This is a promo card given away at SPIEL 2012 in Essen to promote the Belgium Deck. The Brakel is a chicken breed from Belgium, named after a region there. The card is numbered 'FL061'.

Brakelhühner is a minor improvement and costs two food to build, which are put on the card. In every harvest phase, if there are at least two food on this card, it produces one additional food. The food can be taken from this card at every time. If, at game end, there are at least 4 food on this card, it counts as two victory points.

boardgame.description:
Property trading game about the places, plants and animals of the North Shore of Minnesota bordering Lake Superior.
The game utilizes the watercolors of Brian Minor and Rebecca Minor to illustrate the game board, game box and deed cards.
Manufactured individually by hand in Superior, WI by Brian Minor and his family.
Playing pieces are actual pebbles collected from the shore of Lake Superior.
Each property deed has the history of the place you are purchasing. Highlighting interesting educational points of interest.
Each game is individually numbered and signed by the creator/artist Brian Minor

boardgame.name: Dino Path
Guka Croka!
boardgame.description:
"¡Guka Croka!" translated from the much known troglodyte language, means: "HURRY UP, AMONG THE DINOSAURS, WE MUST ARRIVE TO THE CAVE ON TIME TO HAVE DINNER!!"

In this game, each troglodyte must arrive to the cave, only the fastest will be winner, so you need good luck rolling the dice and good memory to remember where dinosaurs hide to escape from them as quickly as you can.

Game is a combination of roll-and-move and memory elements. Players build circuit from hexagonal tokens, each carrying picture of one of 12 dinosaurs, faceup adding "Start" hex as a first one and "Cave" hex as last one. There are 4 addtional hexes that give "special action" - two "ladder" and two "extra roll". Additionally there 12 tiles with same 12 dinosaurs which is arranged in separate 4x3 grid, face down. When arriving at particular hex with dinosaur picture player has one try to find same dinosaur in facedown 4x3 grid - if successfull he rolls a die and moves again. First player to arrive to "Cave" hex wins the game.

boardgame.name: Delfi 10
boardgame.description: Trivia board game published on 10th anniversary of Delfi news site. The players roll a die and step the given amount on the board. Previous player takes a card and reads a task or question to the player. If he/she carries out the task or answers correctly, he/she gains the card and points shown on it. The game ends when the first player reaches the finish on the track. Then the points are added up and the biggest score wins.

boardgame.name: Aarresaari
boardgame.description:
A children's game based on Mauri Kunnas' version of R.L. Stevenson's Treasure Island.

Players have five cards, each of which shows three types of treasure items. The game board has three rotating wheels with the pictures of treasure, and they must be aligned so that the combinations in the cards are shown on the board. On each turn, player gets to rotate the wheels 1–3 steps, depending on a die roll.

After the active player has rotated the wheels, all players check if the combinations in their treasure cards show up on the board. If they do, players can discard the matching cards. Whoever gets rid of her cards first, wins the game.
